Radhika Mohan Maitra (1917  1981) was an acclaimed Indian sitar and surbahar player of the Senia-Maihar gharana, a school of Indian classical music. Born in Kolkata, Maitra's career spanned several decades and was marked by his passion for preserving the traditional and undiluted form of North Indian music.

I. Early Life and Education

Maitra was born into a cultured Bengali family in Kolkata, as the youngest of eight siblings. His uncle, a tabla player, recognized his musical inclination and introduced him to the sarod. He began his formal training with Md. A. Daud, learning to play the sitar. However, it was his encounter with the legendary sarod player, Baba Alauddin Khan, that truly shaped his musical future. Recognizing the young Maitra's talent, he included him among his few surbahar and sitar students.

II. Musical Career 

Maitras professional career began with All India Radio (AIR) in Kolkata. His musical journey was characterized by authenticity and commitment to preserve traditional Indian music in its purest form. He rejected the trend of fusion music that was prevalent during his time and held strong to the principles of the Senia-Maihar gharana. His technique involved playing the surbahara bass sitarin the Dhrupad style that followed the detailed unfolding of the raga. 

Maitras virtuosity and dedication to the sitar and surbahar established him as an influential figure in the world of Indian classical music. His performances were acknowledged for their depth, clarity and soulful quality. He treasured the spiritual essence of Indian classical music and believed that music was a vehicle to attain self-realization.

III. Legacy

Maitra left a lasting impression in the realm of Indian classical music during his lifetime. His rigorous approach to teaching and insistence on preserving the traditional format of North Indian music remains influential on his students, who continue his lineage in professional music. Some of his notable disciples include Joydeep Ghosh, Shyamal Chattopadhyay and Nikhil Banerjee. 

Radhika Mohan Maitra passed away in 1981, but his contributions to Indian music continue to be revered and honored, maintaining his status as a pivotal figure in the preservation and promotion of traditional Indian classical music.

British intelligence agencies are organizations responsible for the collection and analysis of information to support the national security of the United Kingdom (UK). The responsibilities of these agencies encompass foreign intelligence, domestic intelligence, and military intelligence. These agencies are tasked with gathering intelligence on a wide range of issues, including threats to national security, economic stability, and the interests of the UK abroad. As governmental bodies, they report to the government and are subject to legal and parliamentary oversight to ensure their operations comply with UK law. 

The primary British intelligence agencies are the Secret Intelligence Service (SIS), often known as MI6; the Security Service, better known as MI5; and the Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ). 

The Secret Intelligence Service (SIS)/MI6 primarily deals with external threats and foreign intelligence gathering. Created in 1909, its mandate involves safeguarding the UK's national security by investigating issues beyond the country's borders. It works closely with the Foreign and Commonwealth Office, the Ministry of Defence, and overseas organisations.

The Security Service/MI5 is responsible for domestic intelligence. Established in 1909, the same year as SIS, MI5 primarily focuses on internal security within the UK. Its functions include counter-terrorism, counter-espionage, and protection of VIPs and government infrastructure. 

The Government Communications Headquarters (GCHQ) specialize in signals intelligence (SIGINT) and information assurance. Founded in 1919, GCHQ maintains the UK's ability to intercept electronic communications and decipher codes, particularly in the realm of cyber security. 

In addition to these primary agencies, the UK has several more intelligence bodies, including the Defence Intelligence (DI), which works alongside the Ministry of Defence, and the National Crime Agency's Intelligence Directorate, which focuses on serious and organized crime. 

The establishment and operation of these intelligence services have been vital in safeguarding the national security of the UK and its interests worldwide. They operate under the Intelligence Services Act 1994, which provides the legal basis for their activities. Accountability measures include oversight by the Intelligence and Security Committee of Parliament, the Investigatory Powers Tribunal, and the independent Investigatory Powers Commissioner.

British intelligence agencies have played key roles during different historical events, including both World Wars, the Cold War, and the modern era of global terrorism. They've been instrumental in countering threats, thwarting terrorist activities, and investigating organised crime, contributing significantly to ensuring the safety and security of the United Kingdom and its citizens. Lawrence Edward Grace "Titus" Oates (17 March 1880  16 March 1912) was a British Army officer and later an Antarctic explorer, celebrated for his self-sacrifice during Robert Falcon Scott's ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition to the South Pole.

== Early life and career ==
Oates was born in Putney, London to a wealthy family. He was educated at Eton College and then went onto serve in the second Boer War as a lieutenant in the Inniskilling Dragoons.

== Polar exploration ==
In 1910, Oates was selected by explorer Robert Falcon Scott to join the Terra Nova Expedition, which aimed to be the first to reach the South Pole. According to some accounts, Scott chose him for his expertise with horses, which were to be used for hauling supplies.

Despite the team's valiant efforts, they were beaten to the South Pole by the Norwegian team led by Roald Amundsen. On the return journey, Oates began suffering from frostbite and scurvy that slowed the team down greatly. 

On 16 March 1912, Oates famously walked out into a blizzard, stating "I am just going outside, and may be some time", to sacrifice himself and give the remaining team members a better chance of survival. His body was never recovered.

== Legacy and honours ==
Oates's courage and selflessness became legendary and he continues to be honoured in Britain and beyond. Memorials to Oates stand at the Church of St. George in Meanwood, Leeds, and the Scott Polar Research Institute in Cambridge. 

In 1985, the Lawrence Oates School was opened in Farnborough, Hampshire, and in 2012, a Royal Mail stamp was issued commemorating the centenary of Oates's selfless act.

Despite the tragic end, Oates's legendary heroism has become an illustrious part of the history of Antarctic exploration, embodying the spirit of self-sacrifice in the face of insurmountable odds. His story serves as a reminder of human courage and fortitude in the harshest of circumstances.

Produced by long-time collaborator Johnny "J" Jackson and Tupac Shakur himself, "Hit 'Em Up" was released on June 4, 1996, as the B-side to "How Do U Want It", a single from his double platinum album "All Eyez on Me".
